title: Extinction Rebellion needed to close London’s roads to make our point
text:
We’re made up of you: office workers, doctors, teachers, builders and even former police officers (Picture: Henry Nicholls/REUTERS)

This is an invitation to hardworking Londoners going about your business this week and next: we’d like to show you our International Rebellion.

It’s bigger and more spectacular than the last time we took to the capital’s streets in April, and above all, it’s for you.

Because we’re made up of you: office workers, doctors, teachers, builders and even former police officers. We are youth, parents and grandparents. And we are all afraid of what the climate and ecological emergency will bring to you and your loved ones if the government doesn’t act now.

That’s why Extinction Rebellion has returned to London. We’ve blocked roads and locations across Westminster because it’s the only way we can think of to get the government to take notice and act after years of policy making that simply doesn’t touch the sides when it comes to the action that’s needed.

Advertisement

Advertisement

We need to end the fallacy that those of us living in developed economies like the UK will somehow be spared the impacts of climate change already devastating lives elsewhere.

Scientists’ warnings about disappearing glaciers and sea-level rise can feel too distant and remote when envisaged for the years 2050 or 2100. It’s why for over three decades, the climate and ecological crisis just hasn’t felt like one for most people in London.

In this Rebellion we’ll also be drawing attention to nearer-term threats that are frankly even more terrifying (Picture: Ben Stansall/AFP)

In this Rebellion we’ll also be drawing attention to nearer-term threats that are frankly even more terrifying.

Some of us are preparing to go on hunger strike to illustrate the likelihood that our supermarkets will fail us because the food system is too fragile to continually withstand the shocks of extreme weather happening in other parts of the world.

And as this week unfolds, you’ll hopefully hear about a series of peaceful actions in different parts of the capital that will demonstrate, in the clearest and strongest terms.

There will also be a sit-in protest to close City Airport from Thursday, which we hope will demonstrate the absurdity of expanding air travel at a time when carbon emissions from planes need to be radically cut in line with scientific warnings.

An Extinction Rebellion environmental activists being placed under arrest in London Picture: Getty)

We don’t take our actions lightly. We have been in discussions for months with the police and emergency services about precisely what we are planning so as to ensure Londoners and people joining us remain safe.

Advertisement

Advertisement

For example, any emergency within the blockaded area will be accessible to the emergency services. And to minimise disruption, we offered to work with Transport for London to help divert buses, and took it upon ourselves to post advance warnings at impacted bus stops.

And of course, our actions are entirely non-violent, not least because historically speaking, non-violent civil disobedience is effective.

Above all, we have returned to the capital because we are afraid and vulnerable. By admitting this to ourselves and to each other, something wonderful can happen – something that we at Extinction Rebellion want to share with all Londoners, and that is a rebirthing of community and care for one another.

There will be a dizzying display of arts and performances to highlight visions and voices about what our future could be like, if only the government would act. This is a future where our cultures are resilient, regenerative and built on respect for one another, all other forms of life, and the planet that sustains us. A future where we survive.

Rebellion is for all of us, so please, join us at some point over the next two weeks. Bring your family to the XR Families site next to Admiralty Arch or join us in contemplation and prayer at the newly unveiled Faith Bridge (formerly Lambeth Bridge).

Advertisement

The weather won’t wait for our politics, so Extinction Rebellion is demanding government cut carbon emissions to net zero by 2025 and set up a citizens’ assembly to agree how to make that happen. That’s what a successful rebellion will look like.

It will be of course be a massive step, and we are not naive about how far there is to go. But then do Londoners really want to go to hell in a hybrid?

Marc Lopatin is an Extinction Rebellion activist
